column1: Keningau (Malay: Pekan Keningau) is the capital of the Keningau District in the Interior Division of Sabah
column2: Malaysia. It is the fifth-largest town in Sabah
column3: as well one of the oldest. Keningau is between Tambunan and Tenom. The town had an estimated population of 173

column1: The name Keningau is derived from the locally-abundant Javanese cinnamon tree (Cinnamomum burmannii) which is locally known as koningau. The tree is known as 'Kayu Manis' in Malay and is sometimes referred to as the 'king of spices'. Its bark was collected by the British North Borneo Company to be sold as a spice. During the British colonial era
column2: Keningau was one of the most important administrative centres in British North Borneo.

column1: The Japanese used Keningau as one of its main administrative centres during their occupation of North Borneo in World War II.
The Keningau 1 is south of the Keningau Town. There is a vibrant commercial district with some of historical 'shop-houses.'

column1: Keningau's population was estimated in 2010 at 5
column4: 8% are Chinese (of whom most are proportionally divided into Hakkas and Taishanese); the balance is divided between other indigenous Sabahan races and foreign immigrants (legal and illegal) from the Philippines and Indonesia. The latter group forms a disproportionately large part of the population of Keningau as many of these immigrants come to seek employment in the many agricultural plantations in the district.

column2: the indigenous Sabahan ethnicities in Keningau mostly speak English
column3: Malay (albeit a distinct Sabahan creole form of it). The ethnic Chinese population speak Sze Yup (a dialect of Cantonese)
column4: Hakka and Mandarin (varieties of Chinese) among themselves
column5: but generally speak Malay when interacting with members of the indigenous races.

column1: Most of the Indonesian and Filipino immigrants speak Malay in addition to their native languages.
This monument was erected to commemorate Sabah's entrance into the federation of Malaysia by Garukon Gurun
column2: a former Sergeant Major of the legendary North Borneo Constabulary from Kampung Dangulad Keningau. It was unveiled and officiated on 31 August 1964. On the stone is a plaque setting out the federal government's promises to the people of Sabah
column3: as well as the reciprocal promise of Sabahans to remain loyal to the federal government. The stone is in the compound of the Keningau District Office.
making it the largest park in Sabah. The park consists of hill and montane forest
column4: with many species of flora and fauna endemic to Borneo. Maintenance of this forest cover is essential to ensuring a pure water supply for many of the towns and communities in Sabah.

column1: Keningau Hospital is a 212 bed hospital and it is a district hospital providing specialist services for outpatients and inpatients. It is the main hospital in the Interior Division and is visited by patients from the surrounding districts of Nabawan
There are many pharmacies available in Keningau.
The Keningau Regional Library is one of three regional libraries in Sabah
column2: the others being in Sandakan and Tawau. These libraries are operated by the Sabah State Library.
